paragraphs.text: The map provides information on known individual quantitative food consumption data worldwide. Browse the map or use the filters to find surveys of interest, check their availability and view the survey details. Surveys with the status “Data available” have been harmonised and are shared through FAO/WHO GIFT. Available data can be downloaded and visualised through interactive indicators and summary statistics. For additional information, please refer to theMethodologysection.

Please write tofao-who-gift@fao.orgif you are aware of an
                                individual quantitative dietary survey that is not yet included in the map, or if you
                                notice any inaccurate information.

The boundaries and names shown and the designations used on this map do not imply the expression of any opinion whatsoever on the part of FAO concerning the legal status of any country, territory, city or area or of its authorities, or concerning the delimitation of its frontiers and boundaries.Dashed lines on map represent approximate border lines for which there may not yet be full agreement.

Final boundary between the Sudan and South Sudan has not yet been determined.Final status of the Abyei area is not yet determined.Dotted line represents approximately the Line of Control in Jammu and Kashmir agreed upon by India and Pakistan.The final status of Jammu and Kashmir has not yet been agreed upon by the parties.

Acute food consumption per day and/or per kilogram of bodyweight
                                                        per day among High Consumers (or, more precisely,
                                                        high-percentile consumers referring to percentiles 95-99) is
                                                        used to estimate how much of a given food item or food belonging
                                                        to a food group is consumed on the days on which consumption of
                                                        the food of interest occurs.

This information is of particular use for risk assessment when
                                                        the data is combined with the content of potentially harmful
                                                        chemical substances in foods. The result indicates whether the
                                                        presence of this substance in a given food can pose acute
                                                        toxicity risks from consumption of a single meal or through a
                                                        single day (24 hours) of dietary exposure.
This infographic shows the contribution of different foods and food groups to the average dietary intake of different micronutrients expressed in grams per person per day.
This infographic shows the contribution of different foods and food groups to the average dietary intake of different macronutrients expressed in grams per person per day.

This infographic shows the average percentage contribution of macronutrients (fat, carbohydrate and protein) to total energy intake. The values are shown with reference to the recommended by WHO proportions of macronutrients in the diet (see methodology section for references).

The Minimum Dietary Diversity for Women (MDD-W) is a dichotomous indicator of
whether non-pregnant women of reproductive age, 15-49 years old, have
consumed at least five out of ten defined food groups over a 24-hour period. No
information on quantities of foods consumed are needed.

MDD-W is a food group diversity indicator that can be used as a proxy to indicate
an acceptable level of dietary micronutrient adequacy across 11 micronutrients,
including vitamin A, thiamin, riboflavin, niacin, vitamin B6, folate, vitamin B12,
vitamin C, calcium, iron and zinc. The higher the proportion of women achieving
MDD-W, the better the micronutrient adequacy in a given population.

The Minimum Dietary Diversity for Women (MDD-W) is a dichotomous indicator of
whether non-pregnant women of reproductive age, 15-49 years old, have
consumed at least five out of ten defined food groups over a 24-hour period. No
information on quantities of foods consumed are needed.

MDD-W is a food group diversity indicator that can be used as a proxy to indicate
an acceptable level of dietary micronutrient adequacy across 11 micronutrients,
including vitamin A, thiamin, riboflavin, niacin, vitamin B6, folate, vitamin B12,
vitamin C, calcium, iron and zinc. The higher the proportion of women achieving
MDD-W, the better the micronutrient adequacy in a given population.

The Minimum Dietary Diversity for Women (MDD-W) is a dichotomous indicator of
whether non-pregnant women of reproductive age, 15-49 years old, have
consumed at least five out of ten defined food groups over a 24-hour period. No
information on quantities of foods consumed are needed.

MDD-W is a food group diversity indicator that can be used as a proxy to indicate
an acceptable level of dietary micronutrient adequacy across 11 micronutrients,
including vitamin A, thiamin, riboflavin, niacin, vitamin B6, folate, vitamin B12,
vitamin C, calcium, iron and zinc. The higher the proportion of women achieving
MDD-W, the better the micronutrient adequacy in a given population.

This infographic shows the estimated averagegreenhouse
                                                            gas emissions(kilograms of carbon dioxide
                                                        equivalents (kg CO₂ eq)),water use(litres)
                                                        andland use(square meters (m²)) of foods in
                                                        the diet per person per day. This is also expressed by food
                                                        group, subgroup, and items.

The calculations take into account all individuals in the
                                                        population: consumers and non-consumers. Consumers are those
                                                        individuals who consumed the foods of interest during the survey
                                                        period, and non-consumers are those who did not. The
                                                        environmental impact values of foods are based on Poore and
                                                        Nemecek (2018). The system boundaries considered by Poore and
                                                        Nemecek start with the extraction of resources needed to produce
                                                        inputs for agricultural production, end at the retail store, and
                                                        includes processing, packaging, transportation and losses from
                                                        farm to retail point. Further details on the data sources used                                                        
                                                        and methods applied can be found in theMethodology section.

This infographic offers an understanding of the contribution of
                                                        different foods and food groups to the total environmental
                                                        impact of diets, and how the composition of the diet may
                                                        influence its environmental impact.

Three levels of impact (average, low, and high) are considered.
                                                        The main graph is calculated using theglobal
                                                            averageenvironmental impact of each food, based on
                                                        Poore & Nemecek (2018). Two additional graphs present
                                                        hypothetical scenarios showing the environmental impact ofthe same dietif all foods had lower
                                                        environmental impacts (low-impact scenario), or
                                                        higher environmental impacts (high-impact
                                                            scenario). These hypothetical scenarios reflect the
                                                        variation in environmental impact values and the uncertainty
                                                        around estimates using the global means (main graph).

This infographic shows the estimated average greenhouse gas
                                                        emissions (kilograms of carbon dioxide equivalents (kg CO₂ eq)),
                                                        water use (litres) and land use (square meters (m²)) per1000 kilocalories, 10 g of protein or 100 mg of
                                                            calciumreported as consumed, per person per day.
                                                        The calculations take into account all individuals in the
                                                        population: consumers and non-consumers. Consumers are those
                                                        individuals who consumed the foods of interest during the survey
                                                        period, and non-consumers are those who did not. The
                                                        environmental impact values of foods are based on Poore and
                                                        Nemecek (2018). The system boundaries considered by Poore and
                                                        Nemecek start with the extraction of resources needed to produce
                                                        inputs for agricultural production, end at the retail store, and
                                                        includes processing, packaging, transportation and losses from
                                                        farm to retail point. Further details on the data sources used
                                                        and methods applied can be found in theMethodology section.

Environmental impacts of diets are usually reported per weight or
                                                        volume (kilograms or litres) of foods or beverages consumed.
                                                        While this approach is simple and easy to understand, it does
                                                        not express food functionality. Therefore, a metric that
                                                        reflects the function of the food (a functional unit) is
                                                        important to describe its environmental impacts. Dietary energy
                                                        (kcal/day) and protein (g/day) are important for understanding
                                                        food security and different forms of malnutrition, whereas
                                                        calcium (mg/day) is an important micronutrient for bone health
                                                        and several physiological functions. The functional units used
                                                        are aimed at normalising results, and are not intended to
                                                        reflect dietary energy or nutrient requirements.

Three levels of impact (average, low, and high) are considered.
                                                        The main graph is calculated using theglobal
                                                            averageof the environmental impact of each food,
                                                        based on Poore & Nemecek (2018). Two additional graphs present
                                                        hypothetical scenarios showing the environmental impact ofthe same dietif all foods had lower
                                                        environmental impacts (low-impact scenario), or
                                                        higher environmental impacts (high-impact
                                                            scenario). These hypothetical scenarios reflect the
                                                        variation in environmental impact values and the uncertainty
                                                        around estimates using the global means (main graph).

The observed single-day intake data for a nutrient reflects two
                                                        components of
                                                        variation: the variation between persons and the variation
                                                        within a person, the so-
                                                        called day-to-day variation. Since, for the purpose of dietary
                                                        assessment, the long.
                                                        term average nutrient intake of a person provides a better basis
                                                        for further
                                                        analysis, the effect of the day-to-day variation should be
                                                        mitigated. This can only
                                                        be achieved by applying statistical models. Adjusting for
                                                        day-to-day variation
                                                        results in a narrower distribution, with the same mean intake
                                                        compared to the
                                                        original data.

The results are presented as a function of age on the percentile
                                                        scale and can be
                                                        directly compared with Estimated Average Requirements (EARs) or
                                                        Average
                                                        Requirements (ARs) to estimate the percentage of a population
                                                        not meeting their
                                                        nutrient requirements. However, the results of such comparison
                                                        should be
                                                        interpreted with caution given the limitations specific to each
                                                        dataset, the
                                                        available Nutrient Reference Values (NRVs), as well as the
                                                        uncertainty in the
                                                        habitual intake distribution, which is also displayed.

The usual intake distributions were estimated based on datasets
                                                        that contain
                                                        dietary intake data from two or more non-consecutive days for
                                                        the whole or a
                                                        subset of the sample.

Calculations were performed using the Statistical Program to
                                                        Assess Dietary
                                                        Exposure (SPADE).

*Estimated Average Requirements (EARs) for calcium calculated
                                                    based on Recommended Nutrient Intakes (RNIs) established by FAO &
                                                    WHO1using conversion factors2.Sources1FAO/WHO. 2004. Vitamin and Mineral Requirements in
                                                    Human Nutrition, 2nd ed. Rome: FAO.2Allen, L., de Benoist, B., Dary, O. & Hurrell R.
                                                    2006. WHO/FAO Guidelines on Food Fortification with Micronutrients.
                                                    WHO: Geneva, Switzerland.

*Including pregnant and lactatingSourcesEuropean Food Safety Authority (EFSA), Nutrition and Allergies
                                                        (NDA) Panel. 2015c. Scientific opinion on Dietary Reference
                                                        Values for Calcium. EFSA Journal 2015;13(5):4101, 82 pp.
                                                        doi:10.2903/j.efsa.2015.4101

SourcesInstitute of Medicine (IOM) 2011. Dietary Reference Intakes
                                                        for Calcium and Vitamin. D. Washington, DC: The National
                                                        Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/13050.

*Estimated Average Requirements (EARs) for iron, from diets with different dietary iron bioavailability, calculated based on Recommended Nutrient Intakes (RNIs) established by FAO & WHO1using conversion factors2.Sources1FAO/WHO. 2004. Vitamin and Mineral Requirements in
                                                    Human Nutrition, 2nd ed. Rome: FAO.2Allen, L., de Benoist, B., Dary, O. & Hurrell R.
                                                    2006. WHO/FAO Guidelines on Food Fortification with Micronutrients.
                                                    WHO: Geneva, Switzerland.

SourcesEuropean Food Safety Authority (EFSA), Nutrition and Allergies
                                                        (NDA) Panel. 2015b. Scientific Opinion on Dietary Reference
                                                        Values for iron. EFSA Journal 2015;13(10):4254. URL:
                                                        https://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/efsajournal/pub/4254

*Requirements set based on the assumed mixed Western omnivorous
                                                    diet with a maximal bioavailability of iron of 18 percent. The
                                                    estimated bioavailability of iron from a vegetarian diet is
                                                    approximately 10 percent. Hence the requirement for iron would be
                                                    1.8 times higher for vegetarians. Diets in developing countries
                                                    (characterized by low diversity and access to animal-source foods)
                                                    might have very low iron bioavailability approaching 5
                                                    percent.SourcesInstitute of Medicine (IOM) 2006. Dietary Reference Intakes:
                                                        The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements. Washington, DC:
                                                        The National Academies Press.
                                                        https://doi.org/10.17226/11537.

*Based on human milk intake of 0.75 l/daySourcesFAO/WHO. 2004. Vitamin and Mineral Requirements in Human
                                                        Nutrition, 2nd ed. Rome: FAO.

* Dietary Folate EquivalentSourcesEuropean Food Safety Authority (EFSA), Nutrition and Allergies
                                                        (NDA) Panel. 2015d. Scientific opinion on Dietary Reference
                                                        Values for folate EFSA Journal 2014;12(11):3893, 59 pp.
                                                        doi:10.2903/j.efsa.2014.3894

SourcesInstitute of Medicine (IOM) 2006. Dietary Reference Intakes:
                                                        The Essential Guide to Nutrient Requirements. Washington, DC:
                                                        The National Academies Press.
                                                        https://doi.org/10.17226/11537.

Cautionary noticeThe summary statistics displayed are derived from the data selected using the above filters.
                    Statistics should be interpreted taking into account the limitations highlighted
                    in theSurvey
                        Detailsand theMethodologysection.
